qas.question: What politicians pushed for statehood for Puerto Rico?

answers.text: Resident Commissioner Pedro Pierluisi, Governor Luis Fortuño

qas.question: What politician fought against statehood for Puerto Rico?

qas.question: What was the White House stance?

answers.text: the results were clear, the people of Puerto Rico want the issue of status resolved

qas.question: What politicians pushed for statehood for Padilla?

plausible_answers.text: wrote separate letters to the President of the United States Barack Obama

qas.question: How did Congress voice their concerns?

plausible_answers.text: the results were clear, the people of Puerto Rico want the issue of status resolved
Former White House director of Hispanic media stated

qas.question: Who stated "Now it is time for Puerto Rico to act"?

context: Several days after the referendum, the <a0_0><b4_0>Resident Commissioner Pedro Pierluisi<b4_0/>, Governor Luis Fortuño<a0_0/>, and <a1_0><b5_0>Governor-elect Alejandro García Padilla<b5_0/><a1_0/> <a2_0><b6_0>wrote separate letters to the President of the United States Barack Obama<b6_0/><a2_0/> addressing the results of the voting. Pierluisi urged Obama to begin legislation in favor of the statehood of Puerto Rico, in light of its win in the referendum. Fortuño urged him to move the process forward. García Padilla asked him to reject the results because of their ambiguity. The White House stance related to the November 2012 plebiscite was that <a3_0><b7_0>the results were clear, the people of Puerto Rico want the issue of status resolved<b7_0/><a3_0/>, and a majority chose statehood in the second question. <b8_0>Former White House director of Hispanic media stated<b8_0/>, "Now it is time for Congress to act and the administration will work with them on that effort, so that the people of Puerto Rico can determine their own future."
